Hi all,

to open a different discussion stream about JUnit 4.x and JDK 1.4:=


During writing an article about JUnit 4, I spent some time looking into
R=
etroWeaver (http://retroweaver.sourceforge.net/) and JDK backward
compatibi=
lity. Annotations have been supported by RetroWeaver, but access
via reflec=
tion has been missing (which is frequently used by JUnit). See
also http://=
sourceforge.net/forum/message.php?msg_id=3D3405558

I just found, that Retr=
oWeaver has published one week before (Sept. 04th) a
new release 2.0 beta, =
with annotation support. I will have a look inside,
and restart my previous=
 tests again. I will give an update to mailing list.

Bye, Jochen

See also=
 http://www.junitext.org
Some slides at http://www.java-forum-stuttgart.de/=
folien/D5_Hiller.pdf
(german only)



  -----Urspr=FCngliche Nachricht-----=

  Von: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]Im Auftrag von
=
C=E9dric Beust ?
  Gesendet: Mittwoch, 13. September 2006 20:35
  An: junit=
@yahoogroups.com
  Betreff: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4
=


  On 9/13/06, Vishal Vishnoi <vvishnoi@...> wrote:
  >
  > I would al=
so like jdk 1.4 support for Junt4.x. If TestNG could do it, I
  > don't see=
 why JUnit team should not do it. Simply follow what TestNG has
  > done ->=
 http://testng.org/doc/documentation-main.html#jdk-14.

  Indeed, it's very=
 simple (and even fun) to implement: bunch of factories,
  you abstract you=
r annotations behind interfaces, and you're good to go. I
  thought that fa=
ns of design patterns and object-oriented programming would
  go nuts with =
such a fun problem :-)

  --
  C=E9dric
  http://testng.org
